MSE library ranks twenty-second in total volumes
By JAY S. GOODGOLD
According to a recently
compiled survey of the
eighty-one academic libraries in
the United States, the Johns
Hopkins Library ranks
twenty-second in total volumes
and sixty-ninth in volumes yearly
added.
The survey, which was
administered by the Association
of Research Libraries, stated that
Hopkins' library had a total
volume of 2,060,000 with a
yearly increase of 46,904
volumes.
The figures compiled for
Hopkins includes the volumes in.
the Alfred D. Hutzler Reading
Room and the Milton S.
Eisenhower Library, as well as
those volumes in the Medical
School and SAIS Libraries.
Furthermore, according to the
survey, the Hopkins library
ranked within the twentieth
lowest percentile in total
operating expenditures total
salaries and wages for employees
and total material and binding.
David Stam, the Chief
Librarian for Hopkins, cited the
"severe cut in the library's
budget over the past four years"
as the main reason for the
library's low ranking in the
survey.

"We have a $2,000,000
budget. Cornell and Yale (which
have four million and 6.1 million
volumes respectively) each have a
six million dollar budget for their
libraries, and they expend the
same amount of money for the
acquisition of new volumes as we
do for our entire budget." said
Stam.
Other than the money alloted
to ,the library by the school,
Stam stated that the library
receives a "driblet" of federal
funds each year ($5,000) and a
small amount of special funding'
amounting to less than five
percent of the library's total

Several Hopkins students in
conjunction with the Chaplain's
Office and the Maryland Public
Interest Research Group
(MaryPIRG) will begin the
operation of a recycling center
for paper goods this Friday
behind Whitehead Hall.
The recycling center will be
open from 3 to 5 p.m. on Fridays
and 10 to 12 a.m. on Saturdays
for the remainder of the
semester.
In addition, workers of the
recycling center plan to make
daily pick-ups of paper trash
from the administrative offices of
Garland Hall and from the
Gilman Hall post office. Special
trash recycling containers will be
placed in the post office by the

center, according to freshman
Paul Shapiro, one of the students
involved with the center's
organization.
Two dumpsters will be set-up
in the back of Whitehead, the
University's power plant situated
in back of Shaffer Hall. One
dumpster will be strictly for
newspapers bound in 8" bundles
and the other for all other paper
goods.
The paper will be sold to a
paper company, and money from
the sale of the paper will be used
to maintain the recycling center,
Shapiro revealed. The center will
receive approximately $25 to
$30 for bound newspapers, and
approximately $20 for mixed
paper goods, explained Shapiro.

Solutions and problems of the Baltimore City schools
By PATRICE GALLAGHER
Members of a panel discussion
entitled "Solutions and
Problems—The Baltimore City
School System" offered
criticisms and suggestions for
improvement of the school
system at last weekend's
"Sunday Experience". Members
of the panel included Oscar
Helm, member of the Baltimore
City School Board, Ann Emory,
principal of Walbrook Senior
High School, John Crew, deputy
superintendent for Baltimore
City Schools, Chris Beach,
coordinator and former head of
the Johns Hopkins Tutorial
Program and Mrs. Dorothy
Carter, head counselor at Pimlico
Junior High School.
Helm, speaking first,
commented on the financial
situation of the Baltimore city
school system, saying "We have a
great deal of criticism concerning
the kind of studnet we turn out,
yet when it comes'time to submit
our budget, it's cut. even though

we can justify everything in it A
lot of new programs we want to
put in will have to be cut because
innovations are always the first
thing to go."
Helm also dealt with the
problems of the recent strike.
Hard feelings among teachers and
administrators have hurt the
schools, he asserted. "It's up to
the principals to work that out
with the staff," he said.
Besides administration-faculty
relations, the strike is currently
hurting the students. Seniors in
high schools are having difficulty
in applying late to the colleges of
their choice, and younger
students have fallen behind in
studies and must undergo
"intensive review," Helm
explained.
Emory discussed what she
termed "factional attitudes"
prevailing in the school system.
"It's quite important that
citizens and communities have
input, but we should all be
working as one. Citizens are

concerned with only one small
segment of the school
environment, and students are
beginning to develop a selfish
attitude."
Citing interference from social
service institutions in Baltimore,
Emory stated, "Until the school
system become separate from the
social service, we can't offer a
quality education. It takes away
too much from instructional
time." She also considered the
problems of size and lack of
adequate counseling in her
discussion.
Crew mentioned "ethnic
inequality" as a basic difficulty
in the schools. "since 1962-63
there's been a tendency to
encourage this dichotomy." he
said. He also discussed financial
and political effects on
Baltimore's schools.
Beach, citing discipline, the
diagnosis of a child's skills and
the quality of teacher training as
prominent problems, offered
numerous solutions.

Cindermen show great promise
With the advent of spring, the
approaching 1974 track season
promises great success.
Eleven returning lettermen,
among them last year's high
point scorers Gerry Greenfield
and Andy Schreiber, will provide
impetus for the Jays. A talented
group of freshmen will add the
edge needed for a championship
season. Senior Greenfield, who is
the defending MAC high hurdle
champion, appears to be in top
form. Earlier this month, he won
the MAC indoor 50 yard hurdle
championship. Greenfield also
placed fourth in the 440
intermediate hurdles at the MAC
championship last year.
In past years, the Blue Jays

have lacked a blanaced set of
runners. However, the opposite is
true this year. Juniors John
Tetzlaff and Jon Higdon lead the
Jays in the two miles and one
mile races, respectively. In the
880 yard run, lettermen Chuck
Mick and freshman Carig Synder
look strong. Andy Schreiber has
the upper hand in the quarter
mile with Earl Dryer close
behind. The sprints also appear
strong with letterman Lon
Massaglia and newcomer Brett
Miles running.
Perhaps the strongest area of
competition for the Jays is the
field events. Senior Al Schiff
heads the list of shotputters and
is hopeful of breaking the current

Hopkins shotput record this year.
Junior Lou Wolfin and freshman
George Skegas head the way in
the discus. The javelin also boasts
a strong field with lettermen
George Steinfels and John Veil
vying for the top position.'
In the jumping events, veterans
Schreiber and Greenfield are the
leaders. Last year, Schreiber
placed third in the long jump at
the MAC championship. Several
freshmen are also looking
impressive, particularly Chris
Beczak in the high jump and
Miles in the long jump. The pole
vault also appears well manned
with letterman Bill Restrepo and
freshman Bill Martin vaulting
well.
